text: If thousands of people share the same rumour, it means the rumour must be true.
explanation: Viral posts spread fast—even when the information is completely false.

text: If a breaking-news post has no source listed, it’s safe to assume the information is accurate.
explanation: Reliable news includes verifiable sources; unsourced breaking claims should be checked.

text: A screenshot of a tweet or message can be easily edited to spread misinformation.
explanation: Anyone can create fake screenshots using simple image-editing tools or apps.

text: If a post says “Share this immediately!” it’s often a sign of a hoax or scare tactic.
explanation: Urgency pressures people to share before checking the facts.

text: Posts showing dramatic photos are always real and not taken from old events.
explanation: Many hoaxes reuse old or unrelated images to mislead viewers.

text: If a friend shares a post, it means the information must be true.
explanation: Trusted people can unknowingly share incorrect or misleading posts.

text: Scam posts often ask for personal information like your phone number, birthday, or bank details.
explanation: Scammers use fake posts and forms to collect data and steal identities.

text: Deepfake videos can make people appear to say things they never said.
explanation: AI can create convincing fake audio and video; always verify with trusted sources.

text: If a post sounds too shocking, strange, or unbelievable, it should be double-checked.
explanation: Hoaxes often rely on exaggerated or emotional content to get shared quickly.

text: Checking the date of a post is important to avoid spreading outdated news.
explanation: Old posts may be unrelated to current events and can mislead when re-shared as new.
